title: Script/ San Serif
content:
Jane The Virgin logo.  
Ive seen this font around, especially that G.  
Any thoughts to what it is?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [images.jpeg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/typophile.com/files/images_6.jpeg) | 6.26 KB |
author: helvetica bold

comments.content:
Custom letter \_G\_ in a fairly generic sans.  
As for the \_G\_ a somewhat similar script letter is found in Grand Hotel [http://www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/grand-hotel](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/grand-hotel "http://www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/grand-hotel")

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943im_/http:/typophile.com/files/GrandHotel_G_5767.jpg)
  
Slope the \_G\_ 20 degrees right and widen it by q40% and it looks like 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943im_/http:/typophile.com/files/GrandHotel_G_slope20degWidth140pct_5336.jpg)
  
Don

Some more \_G\_ styles Susa Bold

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943im_/http:/typophile.com/files/SusaBold_G_3839.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/hubertjocham/susa/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/hubertjocham/susa/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/hubertjocham/susa/") Gmuender Elan  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943im_/http:/typophile.com/files/GmuenderElan_G_5283.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/rmu/gmuender-elan-pro/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/rmu/gmuender-elan-pro/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/rmu/gmuender-elan-pro/") and the similar Stempel Elan v  
Don

Agree with Don, custom lettering. 2 options for me:  
- Don's approach: mash-up fonts, a basic sans and a script; for instance, the sans could be [Buttacup](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.dafont.com/buttacup.font) and the script [Elan](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/elan) (Don's suggestion), [Lightnin](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/lightnin), [Fontella](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/fontella), [Gillies Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/gillies-gothic), [Kaufmann](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/kaufmann), [Penmanshift](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/penmanshift) (nice this one), [Coquette](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/coquette), [Futura Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/futura-script), [Maison](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/flat-it/ht-maison), [Varga](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/varga) (nice too), [Airstream](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.dafont.com/airstream.font)  
- choose an appropriate sans ( [Buttacup](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.dafont.com/buttacup.font)) and customize letters.  
I like and even if it's different (flare serif) [Highway](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/youngjerks.com/#/highway-typeface) by Dan Cassaro.  
Some ready-to-go options: [Selaive](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/latinotype/selaive), [Merced](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/latinotype/merced), [Brownstone Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/sudtipos/brownstone-sans), [Myra Caps](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/typophile.com/wiki/https%3A/%252Fwww.behance.net/gallery/6367355/Myra-Caps-%28Typeface%29), [Kylie](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/typophile.com/wiki/https%3A/%252Fwww.behance.net/gallery/2721389/Kylie-%28Typeface%29), [Solomon](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/font-fabric/solomon), [Gist](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/yellow-design/gist) (slab and inline... ouch... but same vein), [Peacock](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/justanotherfoundry/peacock)  
Maybe a dead-end but you could have a look to [Nexa Rust](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/font-fabric/nexa-rust) and try to mix Nexa Sans with its Script... Not sure it works though...

Thanks for all the advice! You are all very generous!  
Take a look at the attached logo. Its almost the same which then i thought it was  
a font and not something custom.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943im_/http:/typophile.com/files/2_4532.jpg)

Could combine top half of Elan with bottom half of Lightin

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Lightnin_G_6300.gif)
  
Don

Today's trivia: the story plot is a woman accidentally artificially inseminated by her doctor during an examination. It is a loose adaptation of a Venezuelan telenovela. The title for the telenovela shows that the swash \_G\_ is derived from the graphic of an egg on top and a sperm below

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Juana_5819.jpg)
  
Don
How does a doctor "accidentally" do the deed?

I suppose you have to watch the series to find out :)  
The world of soap operas is replete with such near impossible improbabilities.  
Don

Another suggestion for something similar - [Coquette](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/coquette/) by Mark Simonson is swashy with a monoline stroke and flat terminals.

- Lex

The Church Hill Anglican logo (rejected by the client) is by lettering artist Simon Walker, based in Austin Texas:

[http://www.simonwalkertype.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150320090943/http:/www.simonwalkertype.com/ "http://www.simonwalkertype.com/")

Strong possibility that he (or at least someone with a very similar style) is responsible for the Jane the Virgin custom logo as well.
